publisher.publisher-name: Slavica on behalf of the Institute of Russian Studies at the Hankuk University of Foreign Studies

title-group.article-title: Reading Post-Soviet (Trans)formations of Siberian Identity through Biographical Narrative

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright © 2016 Institute of Russian Studies, Hankuk University of Foreign Studies Each contribution copyright © its author

abstract.p: This article presents the results of empirical research regarding Siberian regional identity with a particular focus on regional identity formation and transformation. Based on biographical interviews with residents of three Siberian cities, it analyzes the processes of regional identity formation in a "resettlement" society and identity (re)construction under conditions of social crisis. In order to capture the individual dimension of such (trans)formation in a resettlement society the authors introduce and use a methodology combining the so-called "actionist" version of the social constructionist approach to identity studies and narrative analysis. The final section of this article offers a detailed analysis of the life stories of three Soviet-generation women, demonstrating different scenarios of regional identity transformation on the level of the individual. The results suggest that the effect of dramatic social change on personal identity depends upon the core identity of an individual. Those whose identity was rooted in the Soviet privileging of Siberian economic development face the hardest challenge. Those who have multiculturalism or such values as work or family at the core of their identities handle the crisis more easily, and the consequences of social transformation for their identities are less severe.
